This weekly bulletin will inform students, parents, and staff about internships,
academic programs, jobs, leadership & community service initiatives, along with
other student opportunities in a variety of fields. Please carefully note deadlines, age
requirements, and other pre-requisites for participation.
For ease of use, these newsletters are organized by different categories, such as
Academic Programs, Business Internships & Jobs, STEM Opportunities, Community
Service, and so on.
These various opportunities utilize different formats. Some are in-person, some
remote, and some will involve a hybrid arrangement. Check each program for their
specific format and schedule. Students should consider applying to any that match
their interests and talents. Some program deadlines are fast approaching – please
do not miss them!
Some highlighted programs in the categories below (often with approaching
deadlines) include:
EVENTS: The Big Apple College Fair is scheduled for Sunday, 9/29 (1:00-4:00pm)
– all students may attend this free event at the Javits Center in Manhattan to meet
college representatives from around the country. There are also upcoming virtual
fairs in October, as well as several information sessions about the prestigious CUNY
Macaulay Honors Colleges program.
BUSINESS: The application for the paid Futures & Options Business Internship
Program has been extended to October 4th – students 16 and older may apply. Their
free Career Essentials program is open to all students – that deadline is September
30th.
And the NYC Student Poll Worker program allows students 17 and older (by 11/5)
to work as paid poll workers on Election Day (when schools are closed). Interested
students may check the link in this section, and contact hblumm@stuy.edu with any
questions; Applications should be submitted by early October.
COLLEGE PREP: College Passport on East 12th street in Manhattan provides free
SAT prep for students – the application deadline is 9/30. The Legacy Network’s
Senior Series is still accepting applications for its fall term weekly college support
sessions – all 12th graders may apply.
LEADERSHIP/GOVERNMENT: The free NSLI International Travel program has
a September 30th remote Information Session about their virtual component from
Librarians of Tomorrow is a year-long leadership/service opportunity from the
Brooklyn Library for current 10th, 11th, and 12th graders. The Brooklyn Library also
offers their Story Teen program for the same grades – students interested in early
childhood education and other interested applicants may apply until October 4th.
MUSEUMS/ART: The Swiss Institute in Manhattan offers paid arts-focused
programs for students 15 and older – the application deadline is September 29th! The
Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Internship Program for current 10th and 11th grade
students is now accepting applications.
The Museum of the Moving Image in Queens invites all students 15 and older to
apply for their Teen Council Internship, in which they will learn about art and
museum management. Opportunities for students are also available at other local
museums, including the Guggenheim and the Noguchi museums.
STEM: Teaching the Brain connects students with an interest in medicine &
healthcare with older mentors who can support their goals in this field – it is open to
applicants from all grades. The application deadline is September 30th!
And the Vet Up Champions virtual program from Purdue University introduces 10th
and 11th graders to the field of Veterinary Science. Students from lower-income,
under-represented, first-generation college backgrounds may apply. And Teach the
Brain
Questions, suggestions, and information about other opportunities are always
welcome and appreciated, and may be sent to Internship/Opportunity Coordinator
Harvey Blumm at: hblumm@stuy.edu - we will share your helpful information with
the Stuy community!

Event Approaching: Divergent Hackathon
“Our hackathon is an exciting opportunity for high school students to develop
innovative solutions within three key pathways: Sustainability, Health & Wellness,
and Education & Accessibility. The event will begin offline on Monday, September
30th, allowing participants to start their projects, and culminate in an in-person event
on October 4th. We will provide mentorship from industry experts, hands-on
workshops, and exciting prizes for the winning teams. On the day of the event, we will
have volunteers to help students finish up their projects (for those who started earlier)
or assist those just getting started.
Students can register and find more information about the hackathon by visiting our
website: https://divergentteams.org/hackathon/ . Teams can consist of up to four
members. If you don't have a team, don't worry! Sign up individually, and we'll match
you with other participants to form a team. Even if you're unable to work on your
project during the week, you can still join us. There will be plenty of time on October
4th to create and submit your project.”
Eligible: All students
Dates: September 30 – October 4
Location: Hybrid: Culminating event at Microsoft Offices at 11 Times Square,
Manhattan
Application Deadline: ASAP
Cost: Free
Link: https://divergentteams.org/hackathon/

learn behind the scenes movie facts and share your reactions in real- time. Post movie,
